title.value: LEARNING TO PLAY ATARI IN A WORLD OF TOKENS
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: LEARNING TO PLAY ATARI IN A WORLD OF TOKENS

extractions.description: This paper introduces Discrete Abstract Representations for Transformer-based learning (DART), a model-based reinforcement learning method that utilizes discrete representations and transformers for both world modeling and policy learning. The paper demonstrates that DART achieves state-of-the-art results on the Atari 100k benchmark without using look-ahead search during inference.

type.justification: The paper conducts experiments and presents results on the Atari 100k benchmark, comparing the performance of the proposed model (DART) against other models.
type.quote: We evaluated our model alongside existing baselines using the Atari 100k benchmark (Kaiser et al., 2019),...

name.justification: The paper focuses on model-based reinforcement learning, utilizing transformers for world and policy modeling.
name.quote: In this work, we introduce discrete abstract representations for transformer-based learning (DART), a sample-efficient method utilizing discrete representations for modeling both the world and learning behavior.

name.justification: The paper leverages transformers for both world and policy modeling, distinguishing it from other reinforcement learning models.
name.quote: We utilize a transformer-decoder architecture, akin to the generative pre-trained transformer (GPT) framework, to model the world, while adopting a transformer encoder, similar to the ViT architecture, to learn the policy

name.justification: The paper introduces the use of discrete representations for world modeling and policy learning in reinforcement learning.
name.quote: we introduce discrete abstract representations for transformer-based learning (DART), a novel approach that leverages transformers for learning both the world model and policy

name.justification: DART (Discrete Abstract Representations for Transformer-based learning) is the primary model introduced and evaluated in the paper.
name.quote: In this work, we introduce discrete abstract representations for transformer-based learning (DART), a novel approach that leverages transformers for learning both the world model and policy.

aliases: Discrete Abstract Representations for Transformer-based learning

is_contributed.justification: The paper introduces DART as a new approach for reinforcement learning.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we introduce discrete abstract representations for transformer-based learning (DART), a novel approach that leverages transformers for learning both the world model and policy.

is_executed.justification: The paper evaluates DART's performance on the Atari 100k benchmark, implying that the model was executed.
is_executed.quote: We evaluated our model alongside existing baselines using the Atari 100k benchmark (Kaiser et al., 2019),...

is_compared.justification: The performance of DART is compared to various baseline models such as DreamerV3, IRIS, SPR, etc.
is_compared.quote: In Figure 2, we present the IQM and optimality gap scores, as well as the mean and median scores. These scores pertain to various models assessed on Atari 100k.

referenced_paper_title.justification: DART is the primary contribution of the paper and does not reference any prior work for its definition.

name.justification: The Atari 100k benchmark is the primary dataset used for evaluating the performance of the DART model in the paper.
name.quote: DART outperforms previous state-of-the-art methods that do not use look-ahead search on the Atari 100k sample efficiency benchmark with a median human-normalized score of 0.790 and beats humans in 9 out of 26 games.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Atari 100k benchmark is based on the work titled 'Model-based reinforcement learning for atari' by Kaiser et al., 2019.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We evaluated our model alongside existing baselines using the Atari 100k benchmark (Kaiser et al., 2019),

name.justification: TensorFlow is a common deep learning library used in many reinforcement learning and machine learning experiments.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper refers to the work by Wolf et al., 2020, which makes extensive use of TensorFlow for implementing transformers.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This motivates the need to use transformers (Vaswani et al., 2017; Lin et al., 2022), which have proven highly effective in capturing long-range dependencies in various natural language processing (NLP) tasks (Wolf et al., 2020)
